repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Urban Development Project and
            Second Urban Development Project : notice of receipt of a
            request for inspection and decision not to register the request

abstracts.cdata!:
On September 5, 2007, the Inspection
            Panel received a Request for Inspection related to the
            Cameroon First and Second Urban Development Projects. The
            request was submitted by inhabitants and people representing
            inhabitants of the Nylon zone, Douala, Cameroon. They claim
            to have been harmed and negatively affected by World Bank
            activities relating to the above-mentioned Projects. In
            their letter to the Panel, the Requesters claim that the
            Projects have led to the destruction of their homes,
            possessions and resources. They state that, as a consequence
            of the Projects, about 500 people were forcefully evicted
            from their homes. They further state that many of these
            people have been without homes since then. According to the
            requesters, the Government and local authorities have
            promised them new houses, but this has not yet happened. The
            requesters assert that until today no compensation has been
            paid nor have they received appropriate housing. Under the
            eligibility criteria of the Panel, the Panel may not
            investigate Projects for which the loan has been closed or
            more than 95% disbursed. Furthermore, paragraph 22 of the
            Panel's Operating Procedures provides that the Panel
            Chairperson will not register Requests if he or she finds
            that the Request is without doubt manifestly outside the
            Panel's mandate. Because the Projects closed,
            respectively, on June 30, 1988, and June 30, 1994, the Panel
            is not registering the Request in the Panel's Register,
            and is advising the Requesters of this decision.

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, with an unlikely sustainability. Although
            the Bank performance is rated satisfactory, its handling of
            project execution was too permissive regarding compliance
            with legal covenants, and audit requirements, reflected in
            the Borrower's deficient performance, whose repeated
            breaches of loan covenants, included the resettlement
            failure (despite availability of resources), failure to
            replenish the special account, and reluctance to follow
            procurement guidelines. Lessons mostly address the
            importance of building stakeholders' commitment, and
            ownership, and, designing sound institutional setup early
            on. Identified reforms to improve urban sector management,
            but relinquished in favor of civil works, confirms the
            absence of Government commitment, an issue which should be
            agreed prior to loan effectiveness. Furthermore, the
            ambitious sector program, featuring a combination of
            physical, and institutional elements, but not consistently
            linked because of weak strategies and unclear prioritization
            of actions, hindered even the usually successful physical
            components. In addition, implementation arrangements -
            critical at project design, and key conditions to project
            success - and, performance indicators, were insufficiently
            considered, which diverted decision-making, and weakened
            project monitoring, respectively.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Urban project has a cost of
            U$S 9.0 M and specifically consists of the improvement of
            urban resources mobilization through the preparation of : a
            fiscal cadastre for Douala and Yaounde, better managment of
            state - owned lands, implementation of an action plan to
            improve billing and collection of municipal taxes and
            financing of income - generating municipal projects.  The
            project further includes a program of civil works for
            completing, upgrading and rehabilitating priority urban
            infrastructure in Douala, Yaounde and secondary cities.
            Lastly, it includes a formulation and implementation of a
            sound policy framework and strengthening of institutions in
            the urban and housing sectors.  This component involves
            policy action plans, the provision of technical assistance
            and finally, the preparation of a program of studies and
            pilot actions to improve management and delivery of basic
            urban service.
